datafield.subfield: Multi-pose system for geometric measurement of large-scale assembled rotational parts

To achieve virtual assembly of large-scale assembled rotational parts based on in-field geometric data, we develop a multi-pose rotative arm measurement system with a gantry and 2D laser sensor (RAMSGL) to measure and provide the geometry of these parts. We mount a 2D laser sensor onto the end of a six-jointed rotative arm to guarantee the accuracy and efficiency, combine the rotative arm with a gantry to measure pairs of assembled rotational parts. By establishing and using the D–H model of the system, the 2D laser data is turned into point clouds and finally geometry is calculated. In addition, we design three experiments to evaluate the performance of the system. Experimental results show that the system’s max length measuring deviation using gauge blocks is 35 µm, max length measuring deviation using ball plates is 50 µm, max single-point repeatability error is 25 µm, and measurement scope is from a radius of 0 mm to 500 mm.

Step 1: the volume of a rotational part is checked to decide whether the part is able to be placed under the gantry (figures, 4(c): #mstaa62e6f04 and, (d): #mstaa62e6f04)
if not, the part is placed beside the RAMSGL (In figures, 4(a): #mstaa62e6f04 and, (b): #mstaa62e6f04)
Step 2: Joint 2 is settled and locked due to where the rotational part is placed (figure, 4: #mstaa62e6f04)

Step 3: Joints 4 to 6 are settled and locked, respectively. With the foregoing discussion, the angle between the laser sensor and surface of rotational parts is decided by the type of surface and controlled by Joints 4 to 6. After these procedures, the correct posture of the 2D laser sensor is determined and the angle of each joint is provided as feedback by the high-precision encoder mounted on the respective joints
Step 4: Joint 1 is moved up or down, and locked to make the distance between the 2D laser sensor and surface less than the measurement range of the sensor (57 mm-103 mm for this sensor)
the moving distance is given as feedback by the photoelectric meter. Besides, the center of the rotational part is aligned to the center of Joint 3

Step 5: Joint 3, driven by a servo motor, is rotated 360°. A rotative angle (0.03°) is given as feedback by the servo motor, captured by a computer, and used as a trigger for storing laser data. After the rotation, the ring area covered by the laser beam is detected. We can return to step 3 to change the posture of the 2D laser sensor and measure another area if necessary
Step 6: after the original laser data is substituted into equation (, 2: #mstaa62e6eqn002), the point cloud data of the rotational part is obtained

Step 7: a method based on the nonsubsampled contourlet transform [, 18: #mstaa62e6bib018,, 19: #mstaa62e6bib019] is used to extract the geometric features of the rotational part. Finally, the geometry of the part is calculated by these features
